'''Joseph Anthony "Joey" Barton''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|Ë|dÊ|oÊ|iË|_|Ë|b|É:|t|Én}}; born 2 September 1982) is an [[England|English]] [[association football|footballer]] who plays for and captains [[Premier League]] side [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] as either a [[Midfielder#Centre midfielder|central midfielder]] or a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]].
Barton was born in [[Huyton]], [[Merseyside]] and raised in a working-class area.<ref name="Joey Barton's damning verdict on football's pampered elite">{{cite news|url=http://www.people.co.uk/sport/football/tm_headline=joey-barton-s-damning-verdict-on-football-s-pampered-elite-&method=full&objectid=18276729&siteid=93463-name_page.html|first=Paul|last=McCarthy|date=2006-12-17 |accessdate=2007-07-11 |title=Joey Barton's damning verdict on football's pampered elite |publisher=''People.co.uk''}}</ref> He began his football career with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in 2002 after working his way through their youth system. His appearances in the senior side gradually increased over the following five years and he made more than 150 for the club. He earned his first [[Cap (sport)|cap]] for the [[England national football team|England national team]] in February 2007,<ref name="England 0-1 Spain">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6330177.stm |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=England 0â1 Spain| last=Sinnott |first=John| publisher=BBC Sport | date=2007-02-07}}</ref> despite his criticism of some of the team's players. He then joined Newcastle United for a fee of Â£5.8 million in July 2007. After 4 years with the Magpies, he joined his current club [[Queens Park Rangers]] in August 2011.
His career and life have been marked by numerous controversial incidents and disciplinary problems,<ref name="4thegameprofile">{{cite web|url=http://www.4thegame.com/club/newcastle-united-fc/player-profile/3601/joeybarton.html |title=4thegame Profile |work=4thegame.com |accessdate=2007-07-13}}</ref> and he has been convicted twice on charges of violence. On 20 May 2008 he was sentenced to six months' imprisonment for [[common assault]] and [[affray]] during an incident outside a [[McDonald's]] restaurant in [[Liverpool]] City Centre.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7409943.stm| date=2008-05-22 |accessdate=2008-05-22| title=Joey Barton is jailed for assault | publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Barton served 77 days of this prison term, being released on 28 July 2008.<ref name="Barton released from jail">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2008/jul/28/bartonreleased|title=Barton released from jail|publisher=BBC|date=2008-07-01|accessdate=2008-07-01 | location=London}}</ref> On 1 July 2008 he was also given a four months suspended sentence after admitting [[assault occasioning actual bodily harm]] on former teammate [[Ousmane Dabo]] during a training ground dispute, on 1 May 2007.<ref name="ABHConviction">http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7482620.stm Barton is sentenced for assault</ref> This incident effectively ended his Manchester City career.<ref name="City wash their hands of Barton after fight at training ground">{{cite news | url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2070318,00.html |date=2007-05-02 | accessdate=2007-09-09 | title=City wash their hands of Barton after fight at training ground | work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London | first=Daniel | last=Taylor}}</ref> Three days after his release, he was charged with violent conduct by [[The Football Association|The FA]] for the assault on Dabo.<ref name="TheFA.com- Barton Charged">{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/Disciplinary/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2008/05/Statement_Barton_charged_July.htm |accessdate=2008-07-31 |title=TheFA.com- Barton Charged|publisher=TheFA}}</ref> In October 2011, some newspaper reports published pictures of him alongside [[Tommy Robinson (English Defence League)|Tommy Robinson]] prompting accusations of links to the EDL. Barton has denied any such links.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/sport/oddballs/878250-joey-barton-slams-edl-after-he-is-accused-of-being-a-member |title=Joey Barton slams EDL after he is accused of being a member |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date=2011-10-11 |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref>
== Early life == Born in Liverpool, Barton is the oldest of four brothers.<ref name="Footballer tells of calls to murder suspect brother">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1503721/Footballer-tells-of-calls-to-murder-suspect-brother.html|first=Nigel|last=Bunyan|date=2005-11-24 |accessdate=2011-12-01 |title=Footballer tells of calls to murder suspect brother |publisher=Telegraph | location=London}}</ref> His parents separated when he was 14 years old and consequently he lived with his father at his grandmother's house on a different estate.<ref name="FourFourTwo: Joey Barton">{{cite news|url=http://fourfourtwo.com/interviews/qanda/35/article.aspx |accessdate=2011-12-01 |title=Joey Barton â Q & A â Interviews â FourFourTwo |publisher=FourFourTwo}}</ref> He has said that his grandmother's influence helped him to avoid getting caught up in a [[Recreational drug use|recreational drug culture]] and attributes his work ethic to his father.<ref name="Joey Barton's damning verdict on football's pampered elite" /><ref name="FourFourTwo: Joey Barton" /> His father, also named Joseph, worked as a [[roofer]]<ref name="Give yourself up Michael, pleads footballer ">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1495408/Give-yourself-up-Michael-pleads-footballer.html|first=Paul|last=Stokes|date=2005-08-03 |accessdate=2011-12-01 |title=Give yourself up Michael, pleads footballer |publisher=Telegraph | location=London}}</ref> and played football semi-professionally for [[Northwich Victoria F.C.|Northwich Victoria]].<ref name="Scrapbook">{{cite news | title=Scrapbook: Joey Barton | work=Manchester City FC vs Liverpool match programme, p41 | date=2007-04-14, Barton's cousin Joshua Wilson also played for Northwich Victoria F.C in the season 2007â2008. }}</ref> Barton enjoyed physical education at his school St Thomas Beckets, which he represented in various sports and was a talented Rugby League prospect. He left school with ten [[General Certificate of Secondary Education|GCSEs]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Joey Barton: What's behind his Twitter philosophy? |first=Tom |last=de Castella |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-14662175 |work=BBC Magazines |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=2011-08-26 |accessdate=2011-12-01}}</ref>
== Club career == === Early career === Barton pursued his dreams of becoming a professional footballer by joining Everton's youth system, but played for Liverpool when he was 14. He underwent trials at [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], but was rejected when it was decided he was too small to become a footballer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11679_2276165,00.html|first=James|last=Pearson|date=2003-09-14 |accessdate=2007-08-01 |title=Barton reveals Forest rejection |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> Barton said his rejection by clubs only made him more determined to succeed as a footballer and prove his detractors wrong.<ref name="Barton:Toffees snub helped me">{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11679_2289148,00.html|first=Paul|last=Higham|date=2004-01-24 |accessdate=2007-08-01 |title=Barton: Toffees snub helped me |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> He made his first appearance for the club's under-17s team in 1999 and played regularly at Academy level for three years. His first reserve team appearance came at the end of the [[2000-01 in English football|2000â01 season]], in his final year as a trainee. Uncertain about Barton's future prospects, the club planned to release him,<ref name="progprofile">{{cite news | title=Profile: Joey Barton | work=Manchester City FC vs Wigan Athletic match programme, p19 | date=2006-01-28 }}</ref> but reconsidered and gave him his first professional contract in the close season.<ref name="Scrapbook"/> Over the next two years, he successfully made the transition from the under-19s to regular reserve football. He was promoted to the first-team squad in the [[2002-03 in English football|2002â03 season]].
=== Manchester City === [[Image:Barton leap.jpg|thumb|upright|Joey Barton heading a ball during a match in 2004.]] Barton would have made his debut for the City first-team in November 2002 against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], had he not lost his shirt after leaving it on the substitutes bench at half-time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11679_2250687,00.html |date=2002-11-25 |accessdate=2007-07-18 |title=Things get shirty for City starlet | publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> He eventually made his first-team debut for the club against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 5 April 2003.<ref>Chris Bailey, [http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/sport/football/manchester_city/s/55/55678_barton_lifts_citys_gloom.html "Barton lifts City's gloom"], ''Manchester Evening News'', 7 April 2003, accessed 1 December 2011</ref> His first senior goal came two weeks later in a 2-0 win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on [[Good Friday]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2936441.stm |date=2003-04-18 |accessdate=2007-07-12 |title=City cruise past Spurs | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He ended the [[2002-03 in English football|2002â03 season]] with a run of seven consecutive starts.
After impressing in his first season at City, Barton was offered a new one-year contract at the club by manager [[Kevin Keegan]], which he signed in April 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/2950239.stm |date=2003-09-22 |accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Barton signs new City deal | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He featured in the first-team more regularly during the [[2003-04 in English football|2003â04]] season and, following a second Premiership goal, was rewarded with a call-up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] squad for their [[2004 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2004 European Championship]] qualifiers against [[Republic of Macedonia national under-21 football team|Macedonia]] and [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal]].<ref name="Platt sings Barton's praise">{{cite news|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U21s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2003/09/64237.htm |date=2003-09-03 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Platt sings Barton's praise | publisher=''TheFA.com''|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20050410212050/http://www.thefa.com/England/U21s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2003/09/64237.htm |archivedate = April 10, 2005|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
An [[FA Cup]] match against Tottenham saw Barton receive the first [[red card (sports)|red card]] of his career in unusual circumstances: at [[half-time]], with his club 3â0 down, he argued with the referee and was sent off although the match was not in progress. In the second half, despite playing with 10 men, Barton's team-mates achieved an unlikely 4â3 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2004/02/05/1038343.htm |accessdate=2007-07-26 |title=Man City write new chapter in FA Cup lore | publisher=ABC news}}</ref> Barton left the [[City of Manchester Stadium]] in anger on 17 April, after not being named in the team to play [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/sport/football.html?in_article_id=452045&in_page_id=1779 |date=2007-05-01 |accessdate=2007-09-14 |title=Barton's roll of shame | publisher=Daily Mail | location=London |first=Simon |last=Watkins}}</ref> However he featured regularly in the 2003â04 season, which he completed with 39 appearances and one goal. His displays impressed City's supporters, and at the end of the 2003â04 season he was awarded with the club's Young Player of the Year award.<ref name="Scrapbook"/>
[[Image:JoeyBarton 14 04 07.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Barton playing for [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] during the [[FA Premier League 2006â07|2006â07 season]].]] Barton sparked a ten-man brawl in a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] on 25 July 2004 after "hacking" at an opposition player.<ref name="Keegan fury at Barton">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/3923995.stm |date=2004-07-25 |accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Keegan fury at Barton| publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Although he signed a new contract on 22 September 2004, which would keep him at City until 2007,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/3679346.stm |date=2004-04-15 |accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Barton earns new deal | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> the club considered sacking Barton in December 2004 after an incident at their Christmas party. He stubbed out a lit cigar in youth player Jamie Tandy's eye,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/manchester_city/s/140/140969_barton_faces_fine_after_party_fracas.html |date=2007-12-22 | accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Barton faces fine after party fracas | first=Peter |last=Spencer | publisher=''Manchester Evening News''}}</ref> after he had caught Tandy attempting to set fire to his shirt.<ref name="Barton fined Â£60,000 for fracas">{{cite news|url=http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/premiership/article26003.ece|first=Sam|last=Wallace|date=2004-12-23 |accessdate=2007-07-18 |title=Barton fined Â£60,000 for fracas |publisher=''Independent Online''' | location=London}}</ref> Barton subsequently apologised for his actions and was fined six weeks' wages (Â£60,000).<ref name="Barton fined Â£60,000 for fracas" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/4124241.stm |date=2004-12-24 |accessdate=2007-07-08 |title=Barton apologises to boss Keegan|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In the summer of 2005, Barton was sent home from a pre-season tournament in [[Thailand]] after assaulting a 15-year-old [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] supporter<ref>Rob Hughes, [http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/02/07/sports/SOCCER.php "Enigmas of 2 tarnished stars"], ''International Herald Tribune'', 7 February 2006, accessed 17 September 2006</ref> who had provoked Barton by verbally abusing him and kicking his shin.<ref name="Profile:Joey Barton">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article550765.ece |date=2005-08-02 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Profile:Joey Barton|first=Jenny|last=Booth|publisher=''Times Online'' | location=London}}</ref> Barton had to be restrained from attacking the boy further by teammate [[Richard Dunne]].<ref name="Barton completes move to Magpies" /> Barton underwent anger management therapy at the order of City manager [[Stuart Pearce]] and paid Â£120,000 in club fines.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11679_2345065,00.html|first=Paul|last=Higham|date=2005-08-06 |accessdate=2007-08-01 |title=Barton asks for help |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> In the autumn of 2005, Barton began a seven-day programme of behavioural management at the [[Sporting Chance clinic]],<ref name="Barton: Rebel with an amazing capacity for trouble">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/barton-rebel-with-an-amazing-capacity-for-trouble-767095.html|date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Barton: Rebel with an amazing capacity for trouble|first=Sam|last=Wallace|publisher=''The Independent'' | location=London}}</ref> a charity set up to help troubled sportsmen and women.
Barton handed in a written transfer request in January 2006, which the club rejected.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/4663950.stm |date=2006-01-30 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Man City reject request by Barton | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> The following day, they also rejected a verbal offer for Barton from [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/4667892.stm |date=2006-01-31 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Man City reject Boro's Barton bid | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> with [[Stuart Pearce]] asserting that a deal could still be made to keep him at the club. During the following week, Barton admitted that he was "a little bit impetuous" in making such a request and agreed to begin negotiations on a new contract at City.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/4684956.stm |date=2006-02-06 | accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Barton to end row by signing deal | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He was rewarded with a new four-year deal, which he signed on 25 July, ending speculation about his future.<ref>[http://www.mcfc.co.uk/news/team-news/2006/july/barton-signs-new-deal "Barton signs new deal"], ''Manchester City official website'', 25 July 2006, accessed 1 December 2011</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.premierleague.com/fapl.rac?command=forwardOnly&nextPage=enPlayerProfile&playerId=256600 | accessdate=2007-07-25 |title=Player Profile | publisher=Premier League |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060221081255/http://www.premierleague.com/fapl.rac?command=forwardOnly&nextPage=enPlayerProfile&playerId=256600 |archivedate=21 Febuary 2006}}</ref>
His behaviour appeared to improve after his participation at the Sporting Chance clinic.<ref name="forengland">{{cite news|url=http://www.squarefootball.net/article/article.asp?aid=2702 | accessdate=2008-03-04 |title=Manchester City: Joey Barton for England? | publisher=squarefootball |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060222204826/http://www.squarefootball.net/article/article.asp?aid=2702 |archivedate=22 February 2006}}</ref> However, on 30 September 2006, television cameras captured Barton exposing his backside to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] fans, following City's injury-time equaliser in a game at [[Goodison Park]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5395778.stm "Police to probe Barton incident"], BBC Sport, 30 September 2006, accessed 30 September 2006</ref> Barton had received abuse from Everton supporters throughout the match and the gesture has since been described as "light-hearted" and "inoffensive" by people involved in football.<ref name="Barton books in" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/funny_old_game/5409860.stm |date=2006-10-06 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Holloway backs 'cheeky' Barton |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> [[Merseyside Police]] looked into the incident, but announced in October that no further action would be taken,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/5395778.stm |date=2006-10-04 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Police take no action over Barton|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> although Barton was fined Â£2,000 for bringing the game into disrepute and warned about his future conduct by [[The Football Association]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/5409082.stm |date=2006-10-10 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Barton gets fine but escapes ban |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In December 2006, Barton received the second red card of his career, for a late two-footed tackle on [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] player [[Abdoulaye Diagne-Faye]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2006/dec/24/match.sport8 |date=24 December 2006 |accessdate=14 November 2010 |title=Anelka at double but Barton in trouble |publisher=The Guardian |location=London |first=Duncan |last=MacKay}}</ref>
Barton's agent [[Willie McKay]] revealed in January 2007 that if any team offered at least Â£5.5 million for Barton, it would trigger a release clause in his contract that would mean City would have to allow Barton to talk to the interested club.<ref name="City dismiss Barton inquiry">{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11671_2402470,00.html |date=2007-01-16 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=City dismiss Barton enquiry | publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> This reportedly prompted [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] manager [[David Moyes]] to make an inquiry to City about Barton's availability.<ref name="City dismiss Barton inquiry" /> However, the next day Barton said "People are trying to unsettle me but I'm happy to stay here".<ref>Andy Hunter, [http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/premiership/article2160027.ece "Barton insists he is staying put but Everton lie in wait"] ''Independent'', 17 January 2007, accessed 13 February 2007</ref>
{{Quote_box| width=25% |align=right |quote="England did nothing in that World Cup, so why were they bringing books out? 'We got beat in the quarter-finals. I played like shit. Here's my book.' Who wants to read that?" |source=Joey Barton<ref>Daniel Taylor, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/frontpage/story/0,,2006818,00.html "Gerrard plays peacemaker over Barton"], ''The Guardian'', 6 February 2007, accessed 13 February 2007</ref> |}}
Following impressive form at club level, Barton received his first call-up to the full [[England national football team|England]] squad on 2 February 2007 for a friendly match against [[Spain national football team|Spain]],<ref name="Barton wins first England call-up">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6319849.stm | date=2007-02-02 | accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Barton wins first England call-up | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> despite his recent criticism of certain members of the England squad for releasing autobiographies after an unimpressive [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]]. He had suggested such players had "cashed in" on the national team's lack of success.<ref name="Gerrard jumps to Barton's defence">{{cite news|url=http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/internationals/article2241394.ece | date=2007-02-06 | accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Gerrard jumps to Barton's defence | publisher=The Independent | location=London | first=Sam | last=Wallace}}</ref>
Barton later received support over his comments and [[Steven Gerrard]], one of the players whom Barton had criticised, praised him for his honesty.<ref name="Barton books in">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6335407.stm |date=2007-02-07 | accessdate=2007-07-08 |title=Barton books in| last=McNulty |first=Phil| publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref name="Gerrard jumps to Barton's defence" /><ref name="Liddle">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/columnists/rod_liddle/article1323623.ece |date=2007-02-04 | accessdate=2007-07-13 |title=Barton has the cheek to usher in a new era| last=Liddle |first=Rod| publisher=''Times Online'' | location=London}}</ref> However, [[Frank Lampard]], who had also released an autobiography following the tournament, publicly stated his disapproval.<ref name="Lampard hits back at Barton jibes">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/6281871.stm | date=2007-01-20 | accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Lampard hits back at Barton jibes | publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Barton made his international debut on 7 February 2007, replacing Lampard in the 78th minute of the 0â1 defeat to Spain at [[Old Trafford (football ground)|Old Trafford]].<ref name="England 0-1 Spain" />
He was arrested on suspicion of assault and criminal damage after an alleged argument with a taxi driver in Liverpool while going to his hotel after a match on 13 March 2007.<ref name="City star arrested over assault">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/6445203.stm "City star arrested over assault"], ''BBC News'', accessed 13 March 2007</ref> He was cleared of this charge in May 2008.<ref name="Barton cleared over taxi damage">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7428263.stm "Barton cleared over taxi damage"], ''BBC News'', accessed 30 May 2008</ref>
Barton displayed his outspokenness once again on 22 April 2007 when he publicly criticised City's performances during the [[2006-07 in English football|2006â07 season]], and described some of the players the club had signed as "substandard".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/6580953.stm |date=2007-04-22 | accessdate=2007-07-22 |title=Barton criticises Man City season|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Following his comments, City's manager [[Stuart Pearce]] banned him from speaking to the media.<ref name="Pearce bans Barton from talking to media after public outburst">{{cite news|url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2066512,00.html|first=Daniel|last=Taylor|date=2007-04-27 |accessdate=2007-07-11 |title=Pearce bans Barton from talking to media after public outburst|publisher=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref>
Barton was fined Â£100,000 and suspended by City until the end of the [[2006-07 in English football|2006â07 season]] on 1 May 2007, following an incident during training when he assaulted his team mate [[Ousmane Dabo]].<ref name="City wash their hands of Barton after fight at training ground" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/columnists/columnists.html?in_page_id=1951&in_article_id=452968&in_author_id=353|date=2007-05-05|accessdate=2007-07-20|title=Biggest victim of === Newcastle United === [[Image:Joeybarton161207.jpg|thumb|upright|Barton warming up prior to playing [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in December 2007.]] Following offers from Newcastle United and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sport.scotsman.com/football_english.cfm?id=884852007 |accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Newcastle fend off West Ham to seal Â£5.5m Barton signing| last=Spellman |first= Daniel| publisher=''Scotsman''}}</ref> Barton joined Newcastle on 14 June 2007 for a fee of Â£5.8 million.<ref name="Barton completes move to Magpies" /> The contract negotiations had become protracted after [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] refused to pay Barton a fee of Â£300,000 to which he was reported to be entitled if he left the club without submitting a request for transfer.<ref name="Barton completes move to Magpies">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/6725067.stm |accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Barton completes move to Magpies| last=Hunter |first= Andy| publisher=BBC Sport | date=2007-06-14}}</ref> [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] consequently raised their initial offer of Â£5.5 million to Â£5.8, in effect compensating Manchester City for the Â£300,000 discrepancy. He said that his desire to win trophies helped him to make the decision,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/article232360.ece|first=Steve|last=Brenner|date=2007-06-07 |accessdate=2011-12-01 |title=Barton: It's time to win things|publisher=''The Sun Online''|location=London}}</ref> along with his admiration for manager [[Sam Allardyce]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.inthenews.co.uk/sports/football/rugby-league/premiership-teams-2007-2008/newcastle/barton-joins-newcastle-$1099587.htm|date=2007-06-14 |accessdate=2007-07-24 |title=Barton joins Newcastle |publisher=''inthenews.co.uk''}}</ref> Barton made his Newcastle debut in a friendly against [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] on 17 July 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://icnewcastle.icnetwork.co.uk/newcastleunited/chroniclesport/tm_headline=hartlepool-united-1-newcastle-united-3&method=full&objectid=19470492&siteid=50081-name_page.html|date=2007-07-17|accessdate=2007-07-20|title=Hartlepool United 1, Newcastle United 3| last=Ryder|first=Lee|publisher=icNewcastle}}</ref> Four days later, he was ruled out for six to seven weeks after fracturing the fifth [[metatarsal]] bone in his left foot during a friendly match with [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_2621462,00.html|date=2007-07-22|accessdate=2007-07-22|title=Magpies confirm Barton blow| last=Pearson|first=James|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> He was ruled out for a further month in October 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7022059.stm|date=2007-10-01|accessdate=2007-10-01|title=Newcastle hit by Barton setback|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He eventually made his Premier League debut for Newcastle on 22 October 2007, coming on as a second half substitute in a 3â1 win over Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7043010.stm|date=2007-10-22|accessdate=2007-10-23|title=Newcastle 3â1 Tottenham|publisher=BBC Sport | first=Chris | last=Bevan}}</ref> During his first [[Tyne-Wear derby]] for Newcastle against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], Barton appeared to raise his foot dangerously in a challenge with Sunderland's [[Dickson Etuhu]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7076643.stm|date=2007-11-10|accessdate=2007-11-13|title=Sunderland 1â1 Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport | first=Phil | news|url=http://www.newsoftheworld.co.uk/1111_ban_joey.shtml|date=2007-11-10|accessdate=2007-12-04|title=Ban Him: Bad boy Barton facing FA rap|publisher=News of the World|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080609215730/http://www.newsoftheworld.co.uk/1111_ban_joey.shtml|archivedate=2007-11-07}}</ref> However the FA were unable to charge Barton for the incident because match official [[Martin Atkinson]] had seen the act take place in the match, and had taken no action. FIFA regulations dictate that a retrospective charge for violent conduct can be made only if the match official did not notice the incident. Barton later apologised for the tackle.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7089442.stm|date=2007-11-13|accessdate=2007-11-13|title=Barton apologises for high tackle|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Early in December, he called for Newcastle fans to give the team more time after their abuse of manager Sam Allardyce, calling them "vicious".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7122616.stm|date=2007-12-01|accessdate=2007-12-01|title=Newcastle fans vicious â Barton|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He later played this down, saying his comments had been misrepresented.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10278~1183723,00.html|date=2007-12-05|accessdate=2007-12-05|title=Joey BarToon: Fans Are Crucial|publisher=nufc.co.uk|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071213073142/http://www.nufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10278~1183723,00.html|archivedate=13 December 2007}}</ref>
On 27 December 2007, Barton was arrested on suspicion of assault in the Church Street area of [[Liverpool]] city centre following an incident which took place at 5:30 am.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/footballNews/idUKL2728171420071228|date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2008-04-05 |title=Newcastle's Barton charged with assault |publisher=Reuters UK'' | first=Luke | last=Baker}}</ref> He was remanded in custody on 28 December since the offence was committed whilst he was on bail for two prior offences; the presiding magistrate noted "I also have to consider the safety of the public â you lashed out indiscriminately".<ref>{{cite news | title = Newcastle Footballer Joey Barton Denied Bail, Locked Up On Assault Charge| url = http://news.sky.com/home/article/1298522| publisher = Sky News| date = 2007-12-28| accessdate = 2011-12-01}}</ref> CCTV showed Barton punching a man twenty times, causing him to lose consciousness, and attacking a teenager, breaking some of his teeth. On 20 May 2008, he was sentenced to six months in jail after pleading guilty for his part in the December 2007 assault. Barton's cousin, Nadine Wilson and his brother Andrew Barton also pleaded guilty to their part in the assaults and received suspended sentences.<ref name="Joey Barton is jailed for assault">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7409943.stm|date=2008-05-20|accessdate=2008-05-20|title=Joey Barton is jailed for assault |publisher=bbc.co.uk/sport}}</ref> Barton admitted to being an [[alcoholic]] and claimed he wanted to achieve "total abstinence" in order to improve his behaviour.<ref name="Joey Barton is jailed for assault" /> He served 77 days of his prison term, being released on 28 July 2008.<ref name="Barton released from jail"/>
Barton's subsequent conviction for the earlier assault on [[Ousmane Dabo]] at Manchester City was handed out while serving this sentence.<ref name="ABHConviction" /> He returned to playing action on 30 August 2008, six days before his FA hearing, as a second half substitute during Newcastle's 3â0 defeat to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. He came on to a chorus of boos from the Arsenal supporters.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7578425.stm |title=Arsenal 3â0 Newcastle |date=2008-08-30 |accessdate=2008-08-30 |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera}}</ref> Shortly into this return game, Barton was involved in an incident with [[Samir Nasri]], putting in a strong tackle, for which the referee did not give a foul. The tackle, though hard, was legal. Minutes later, Nasri deliberately clipped Barton while tracking back, for which he was booked. At the end of the game, then-Newcastle manager, [[Kevin Keegan]], was involved in an altercation with Nasri and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] captain [[William Gallas]], in regards to the incident.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=568042&sec=england&&cc=3888 |title=Keegan keen to defend bad boy Barton |date=2008-08-30 |accessdate=2008-08-30 |publisher=ESPN Soccernet}}</ref>
It was a brief stint back in the playing squad, with Barton banned for six games, with a further suspended six-game ban, for his assault on Dabo.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7599647.stm |title=Banned Barton to miss six matches |date=2008-09-05 |accessdate=2008-11-05 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> After serving his ban, he played 75 minutes in a reserve game and said he wanted to transform his image to become a role model,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7683293.stm |title=Barton could make return in derby |date=2008-10-21 |accessdate=2008-11-05 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7685293.stm |title=I want to be role model â Barton |date=2008-10-23 |accessdate=2008-11-05 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> before he returned to action in the [[Tyne-Wear derby]] on 25 October. He was booed by [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] fans and had missiles thrown at him as he warmed up, as Newcastle lost 2â1.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7674086.stm |title=Sunderland 2â1 Newcastle |date=2008-10-25 |accessdate=2008-11-05 |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Owen |last=Phillips}}</ref> It was later confirmed that Barton would be out for two months with a medial ligament injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7733109.stm |title=Barton ruled out for two months |date=2008-11-17 |accessdate=2008-11-17 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Returning to the first team at the end of January, he played only twice before again breaking his metatarsal, during a 2â1 defeat to his old club Manchester City.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/newcastle-united/4378941/Joey-Bartons-season-in-ruins-as-Newcastle-wait-on-Michael-Owen-verdict.html |title=Joey Barton's season in ruins as Newcastle wait on Michael Owen verdict |date= 29 January 2009 |accessdate=14 November 2010 |publisher=The Telegraph |location=London |first=Rob |last1=Stewart}}</ref>
[[Image:Joey Barton corner.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Barton taking a corner in 2010.]] In his first appearance in over three months on 3 May 2009, Barton was sent off late in a 3â0 loss to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] for a sliding challenge on [[Xabi Alonso]]. The red card ruled Barton out of Newcastle's remaining three games of the season, with the club in danger of relegation from the Premier League. Newcastle manager [[Alan Shearer]] raised doubts about Barton's future at the club, saying "I think it would be wrong to discuss his future now, but I'm not very happy."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/8031815.stm|title=Barton 'stupidity' riles Shearer|publisher=BBC Sport| date=3 May 2009| accessdate=3 May 2009}}</ref> On 5 May, Newcastle United announced the suspension of Barton indefinitely, and Barton was told to stay away from the club. As a result, Barton's future at Newcastle United was put in doubt.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/8033495.stm|title=Barton hit by Magpies suspension |publisher=BBC Sport| date=5 May 2009| accessdate=5 May 2009}}</ref> The club suspension was widely reportedly to have resulted not directly from the red card, but from a dressing room confrontation with Shearer and assistant manager [[Iain Dowie]] following the game. Shearer said he made a mistake putting Barton back into the team, and that his tackle was "a coward's tackle", to which Barton replied that he was "the best player at the club", and Shearer had to play him. Shearer said that Barton wasn't, that he was "shit".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/9/england/2009/05/05/1247140/report-joey-barton-blasts-newcastle-united-manager-alan-shearer|title=Joey Barton Blasts Newcastle United Manager Alan Shearer|publisher=Goal.com| date=5 May 2009| accessdate=5 May 2009}}</ref> Barton replied that Shearer was "a shit manager with shit tactics". When Dowie intervened, Barton called him "a prick".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/may/06/joey-barton-alan-shearer-newcastle-united|title=Barton hopes to patch things up with Shearer|publisher=Guardian Football| date=6 May 2009| accessdate=10 May 2009 | location=London | first=Louise | last=Taylor}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/barton-on-way-out-of-newcastle-1679652.html|title=Barton on way out of Newcastle|publisher=The Independent| date=6 May 2009|accessdate=6 May 2009 | location=London | first=Michael | last=Walker}}</ref> Barton was reportedly transfer listed, with former manager Sam Allardyce reported to have been interested in taking Barton to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]. Barton's counsellor has said that Barton "would love to work with Alan Shearer again" and "feels very much that he owes the club and the fans."
Barton stayed on with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] after they were relegated to the [[Football League Championship|Championship]], playing six out of Newcastle's opening eight league games, but suffered an injury to his foot in a 3â1 win against [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] on 19 September.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2557/news/2010/03/16/1835776/newcastle-united-midfielder-joey-barton-steps-up-his | work=Goal | title=Newcastle United midfielder Joey Barton steps up his comeback from injury | date=16 March 2010}}</ref> He returned in April for Newcastle, playing all nine of Newcastle's remaining league fixtures and scoring his only goal of the campaign from a free kick in a win over [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8572945.stm | work=BBC News | title=Doncaster 0 - 1 Newcastle | date=23 March 2010}}</ref> Due to the form of [[Danny Guthrie]] and [[Kevin Nolan]], Barton had to play left wing when he returned.
He started his new club season 2010â2011 as a first team regular, playing against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on the opening day. On Barton's and Newcastle's second game, he scored against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in a 6â0 victory for Newcastle. Immediately, after the game Barton removed a moustache which he had pledged to not shave until Newcastle United had won a game in the new season. On 10 November, in a 2â1 defeat to Blackburn, Barton again acted violently, punching [[Morten Gamst Pedersen]] in the chest. He was not punished during the game as the officials did not see the incident, but after reviewing the evidence,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9178056.stm | work=BBC News | title=Referee to review Joey Barton 'punch' on Pedersen | date=2010-11-11}}</ref> the FA again charged Barton with violent conduct.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/9181426.stm | work=BBC News | title=Newcastle's Joey Barton charged over alleged punch | date=2010-11-11}}</ref> Barton apologised, accepted the charge, and was banned for three matches.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/9181426.stm | work=BBC News | title=Banned Joey Barton 'sorry' for Pedersen punch | date=2010-11-11}}</ref> Barton courted controversy once again during Newcastle's 3â1 win over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 11 December 2010, when he appeared to direct homophobic remarks and a lewd gesture at [[Fernando Torres]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.whoateallthepies.tv/liverpool/59099/did-joey-barton-call-fernando-torres-a-fking-poof-photo.html | location=London | work=whoateallthepies | title=Did Joey Barton call Fernando Torres a "F**king Poof"? | first=Ollie | last=Irish | date=2010-12-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1338548/Joey-Barton-reminded-responsibilities-FA-following-gestures-Fernando-Torres.html#ixzz1Cr7rnxqK | location=London | work=The Daily Mail | title=Joey Barton skips punishment and 'reminded of his responsibilities' by FA following gestures at Fernando Torres | date=2010-12-14}}</ref> Barton scored two penalties against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 5 February 2011 as Newcastle came from a 4â0 deficit to draw 4â4. He was involved in an altercation with [[Abou Diaby]] which led to a straight red card for Diaby. Diaby took offence to Barton's strong challenge and retaliated by grabbing Barton by the neck and shoving him to the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/match-menu/3284307/first-team/newcastle-united-v-arsenal?tab=report |title=Newcastle United 4-4 Arsenal - Match Report | Fixtures & Reports | Fixtures |publisher=Arsenal.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Match/Report/0,,10278~2286076,00.html |title=Newcastle United | Match | Match Reports | Newcastle United 4 Arsenal 4 |publisher=Nufc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref>
On 25 May 2011, Barton's agent [[Willie McKay]] confirmed that his client would not be signing a new contract at [[St James' Park]] after contract talks broke down between the club and player.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13546072.stm | work=BBC Sport | title=Joey Barton set for Newcastle United departure | date=2011-05-25}}</ref> Barton was officially transfer listed by Newcastle on 1 August 2011, and it was also stated that he could leave for free with his current contract yet to expire.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20110801/barton-placed-on-transfer-list_2281670_2407238 | publisher=Newcastle United FC | title=Barton Placed On Transfer List | date=2011-08-01 | date=2011-08-02}}</ref> Barton was set to join West Ham United following his teammate [[Kevin Nolan]], who earlier joined West Ham, but Barton insisted on not moving.<ref>{{cite news|author=Magpies midfielder would be happy to stay put |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6991026,00.html |title=Barton doesn't want to leave |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2011-06-15 |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref> Joey Barton also criticised the Newcastle board after it was decided he could leave the club on a free transfer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_7076222,00.html |title=Barton criticises Toon board |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2011-08-02 |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref> With Newcastle continuing to decline the offer of a new contract, after he refused an earlier offer, on 24 August 2011,<ref name =QPRmedical24082011>{{Cite news | title = Joey Barton has medical ahead of proposed Queens Park Rangers move | publisher = Guardian.co.uk | date = 2011-08-24 | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/aug/24/joey-barton-qpr-newcastle-transfer | accessdate = 2011-08-27 | location=London | first=Louise | last=Taylor}}</ref> Barton was given permission to talk to QPR. Thanking the Newcastle fans, he left on 26 August 2011.<ref name=leftNufc>{{cite web | title = Joey Barton thanks NUFC fans after joining QPR | publisher = hartlepoolmail.co.uk| url = http://www.hartlepoolmail.co.uk/sport/football/newcastle-utd/joey_barton_thanks_nufc_fans_after_joining_qpr_1_3720656 | accessdate = 2011-08-27}}</ref>
A week before his signing with QPR, Barton was involved in an altercation with [[Gervinho]] of Arsenal, which got Gervinho got sent off on his debut. Then, [[Alex Song]] stamped on Barton, for which Song received a three-match ban. Barton later revealed he was on a verge of joining Arsenal but his incident with Gervinho ended his hopes of a move to the Emirates and instead, he joined [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Press Association |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/sep/21/joey-barton-gervinho-arsenal |title=Joey Barton claims Gervinho incident scuppered hope of move to Arsenal|publisher=Guardian |date= 2011-09-21|accessdate=2011-10-24 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Silva |first=Michael Da |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15008071.stm |title=BBC Sport - Joey Barton claims Gervinho incident stopped Arsenal move |publisher=BBC News |date=2011-09-21 |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref>

== International career == Barton represented the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] and was part of the squad for their [[2004 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2004 European Under-21 Championship]] qualifiers against [[Republic of Macedonia national under-21 football team|Macedonia]] and [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal]], scoring once against Portugal.<ref name="Platt sings Barton's praise"/>
Following impressive form at club level, Barton received his first call-up to the full [[England national football team|England]] squad on 2 February 2007 for a friendly match against [[Spain national football team|Spain]],<ref name="Barton wins first England call-up"/> despite his recent criticism of certain members of the England squad for releasing autobiographies after an unimpressive [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]]. He had suggested such players had "cashed in" on the national team's lack of success.<ref name="Gerrard jumps to Barton's defence"/>
Barton later received support over his comments and [[Steven Gerrard]], one of the players whom Barton had criticised, praised him for his honesty.<ref name="Barton books in"/><ref name="Gerrard jumps to Barton's defence" /><ref name="Liddle"/> However, [[Frank Lampard]], who had also released an autobiography following the tournament, publicly stated his disapproval.<ref name="Lampard hits back at Barton jibes"/> Barton made his international debut on 7 February 2007, replacing Lampard in the 78th minute of the 0â1 defeat to Spain at [[Old Trafford (football ground)|Old Trafford]].<ref name="England 0-1 Spain"
== Style of play == Early in his career, Barton mainly played a defensive role,<ref name="The Opta Audit: Joey Barton">{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/manchester_city/s/66/66583_barton_gets_england_call.html|accessdate=2007-08-05 |title=Barton gets England call | date=2007-07-23| publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> with a game based on tackling and tracking back to shield the defence.<ref name="Gilberto v Joey Barton">{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?thisNav=the+match&article=412210&lid=fixture_298346&Title=Head+to+head:+Gilberto+v+Joey+Barton |accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Head to head: Gilberto v Joey Barton | first=Mo |last=Khan| publisher=Arsenal.com|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930181659/http://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?thisNav=the+match&article=412210&lid=fixture_298346&Title=Head+to+head:+Gilberto+v+Joey+Barton |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> As his career has progressed, he has begun to incorporate a more attacking approach to his play, which has resulted in a greater number of goals and assists, and he was Manchester City's leading scorer in 2006â07, despite not playing as a [[striker]].
Barton has been described as having a good work ethic and the ability to carry the ball and retain possession for the team.<ref name="Gilberto v Joey Barton" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2007/05/02/sfnbar202.xml |accessdate=2007-07-11 |title=Talent overshadowed by temper | first=Ian |last =Whittell | date=2007-05-23 | publisher=Telegraph | location=London}}</ref> He has been praised for having a good passing range.<ref name="Barton books in" /> This aspect of his game has shown improvement since the [[2005-06 in English football|2005â06 season]], when he began to favour simpler passes over more ambitious ones,<ref name="forengland" /> and his relatively high pass completion rate can be attributed to this change.<ref name="Gilberto v Joey Barton"/> Barton's passes have often proved to be crucial; in the past he has led the way in his team's [[Assist (football)|assists]].<ref name="City would miss Barton - Opta">{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11679_2343043,00.html |accessdate=2007-07-13 |title=City would miss Barton â Opta | date=2005-07-26 | first=Paul |last =Townley | publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
Barton has been described as the dirtiest player in the premiership,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/s/211/211133_stu_braced_for_barton_bids.html |accessdate=2007-07-13 |title=Stu braced for Barton bids | date=2006-04-20 | first=Mike |last =Whalley | publisher=''Manchester Evening News''}}</ref> a style reflected in the high number of fouls he has committed during his career.<ref name="ESPNprofile">{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/players/stats?id=27050&cc=5739 |title=ESPNsoccernet Profile |work=ESPNsoccernet |accessdate=2007-07-13}}</ref> He received 39 [[Misconduct (football)|bookings]] and three red cards during his time at Manchester City.<ref name="soccerbase">[http://www.soccerbase.com/players_details.sd?playerid=34138 Joey Barton Statistics], www.soccerbase.com â The Internet Soccer Database. Retrieved on 10 July 2007.</ref> This physical approach was occasionally criticised by [[Kevin Keegan]] as excessive.<ref name="Keegan fury at Barton" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/manchester_city/s/53/53467_keegan_backs_barton_to_shine.html|title=Keegan backs Barton to shine |work=Manchester Evening News |accessdate=2007-08-18}}</ref> Opta statistics rated Barton as the tenth best tackler in the [[Premier League]] for the 2004â05 season.<ref name="City would miss Barton - Opta" />

== Personal life == Barton's brother Michael Barton, was sentenced to life imprisonment (with a tariff of 17 years) for his involvement in the racially motivated murder of [[Murder of Anthony Walker|Anthony Walker]] in 2005.<ref name="Cousins jailed for racist axe murder">{{cite news | title = Cousins jailed for racist axe murder | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/race/story/0,11374,1655341,00.html?gusrc=rss | publisher = Guardian Unlimited | date = 2005-12-01 | accessdate = 2007-06-05 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Oliver}}</ref> Joey made a public appeal to his brother to come forward and help with the police investigation following the attack, and also made a series of calls to Michael, enquiring about his involvement in the incident.<ref name="Profile:Joey Barton" /><ref>{{cite news | title = Axe jury hears player's statement | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/merseyside/4459864.stm | publisher = BBC News | date = 2005-11-22 | accessdate = 2007-07-09}}</ref>
In May 2005 he broke a 35-year-old pedestrian's leg while driving his car through [[Liverpool]] city centre at 2 am.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/newcastle/article2581253.ece|date=2007-10-03 |accessdate=2008-03-04 |title=Joey Barton feels Manchester City fans owe him a debt |publisher=''Times Online'' | location=London |first=Anushka |last=Asthana}}</ref> He was arrested on suspicion of assault and criminal damage after an alleged argument with a taxi driver in Liverpool while going to his hotel after a match on 13 March 2007.<ref name="City star arrested over assault"/> He was cleared of this charge in May 2008.<ref name="Barton cleared over taxi damage"/>
Barton is a patron of the Tamsin Gulvin Fund,<ref name="Adams sees Barton in England role" /> a charity set up to support people who have addiction problems and no financial support. [[Tony Adams (footballer)|Tony Adams]], who had been impressed with Barton's attitude during his involvement in the [[Sporting Chance clinic]], appointed him to this role.<ref name="Adams sees Barton in England role">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/4594584.stm |date=2006-01-09 |accessdate=2007-07-09 |title=Adams sees Barton in England role | last=Austin |first=Simon| publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He is a part of the 'Get Hooked on Fishing' campaign, designed to keep children out of trouble by encouraging them to take up [[fishing]].<ref name="Newcastle star gets hooked on fishing">{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisthenortheast.co.uk/display.var.1637161.0.newcastle_star_gets_hooked_on_fishing.php |date=2007-08-22 |accessdate=2007-08-23 |title=Newcastle star gets hooked on fishing | last=King |first=Dan| publisher=The Northern Echo}}</ref> He has also taken part in a celebrity [[cricket]] match for charity to help fund a new children's rehabilitation unit at a hospital in [[Manchester]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/ashes2006/display.var.1457280.0.football_stars_head_for_the_other_old_trafford.php|first=Sudlow|last=Chris|date=2007-06-08 |accessdate=2007-07-11 |title=Football stars head for the other Old Trafford|publisher=''theboltonnews.co.uk''}}</ref>
He is a good friend of the [[Boxing|boxer]] [[Ricky Hatton]] and has supported him in some of his fights,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/8699/Ricky+backs+Barton+to+be+a+hit|accessdate=2007-07-10 |title=Ricky backs Barton to be a hit | date=2007-06-03 | first=Greg | last=Makin | publisher=''Daily Express''}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/article238705.ece|date=2007-06-24|accessdate=2011-12-01|title=Stars out in force for Ricky| last=Haigh|first=Andrew|publisher=''The Sun Online''|location=London}}</ref> and has trained with him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/columnists/article3013673.ece|date=2007-12-07|accessdate=2008-01-17|title=Iâm in a privileged position, but guests do make me envious| last=Logan|first=Gabby|publisher=''The Times'' | location=London}}</ref> He is also a friend of former [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] band member [[Noel Gallagher]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/manchester_city/s/1009/1009076_its_pure_city_says_noel.html|date=2007-06-13|accessdate=2007-07-22|title='It's pure City' says Noel| last=Whalley|first=Mike|publisher=''Manchester Evening News''}}</ref> Barton co-owns a [[Horse racing|race horse]] called 'Crying Lightning' (Named after the [[Arctic Monkeys]] song) with fellow football player [[Claudio Pizarro]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/racing/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=racing/10/06/01/RACING_Leicester_Comments.html|accessdate=2011-02-03|title=Comedy Looks No Joke - Horse Racing News |publisher=''Sporting Life''}}</ref> In January 2011 the horse competed at the [[Nad Al Sheba Racecourse]] in [[Dubai]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/racing/article-1345991/Newcastle-star-Joey-Bartons-horse-Crying-Lightening-break-new-ground-Dubai.html|accessdate=2007-07-22|title=Newcastle star Joey Barton's horse Crying Lightening to break new ground in Dubai|last=Milnes|first=David|publisher=''Daily Mail''|location=London}}</ref>
Barton is a prominent user of [[Twitter]], boasting 824,000 followers as of November 2011.<ref name="twit">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-14662175|title=Joey Barton: What's behind his Twitter philosophy?|last=de Castella|first=Tom|date=26 August 2011|work=BBC News Magazine|accessdate=26 August 2011}}</ref> Commenting on figures from [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] and [[George Orwell]] to [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] and [[Morrissey]]; his eclectic tweets have resulted in him being described by the BBC as "as a philosophical sportsman to rival [[Eric Cantona]] in his heyday".<ref name="twit" />
